creator: cwoodwilson

title: My startup's webgl app lags in FireFox, unless I profile with screenshots on
content:
I am a startup founder. I'm making a webgl rendering engine. I'm doing a stress test with 4 large paragraphs amounting to tens of millions of triangles on a macbook air. Firefox is on the latest version.

When I run the app in chrome/safari/opera, the performance is normal. ~45fps. But in Firefox, it's very slow. My FPS counter (in a requestAnimationFrame loop) says ~45fps on all browsers. But in Firefox, even though the counter says that, the real frame rate is ~3-5fps.

When I try to profile, the problem magically goes away and we're back to ~45fps. I played around with profiler settings, and the key determinant is whether or not I'm taking screenshots. No screenshots = slow. Screenshots = fast.

In the flame graph, in slow mode (no screenshots), it seems like I get stuck in the canvasRenderer and the Renderer mostly waits for it. But in fast mode (with screenshots), the canvasRenderer keeps up and the Renderer spents most it's time in: iokit_user_client_trap

I'm not sure what to do. This is only a problem on Firefox. There's some sort of gpu/threads/something that switches when I profile with screenshots that makes it way faster. This performance hit basically ruins my app for Firefox only. Any idea what I should do?
creator: ben181

title: How to allow for self signed certificates?
content:

Error code: SSL_ERROR_BAD_CERT_ALERT

How to disable security in FF so I can test my endpoint?

title: Exploring the Synergy: Firefox and Intel Evo Technology Integration for Enhanced Performance and Security
content:
Greetings Firefox enthusiasts and Intel Evo laptop users,

As technology continues to evolve, so too does the collaboration between software and hardware to provide users with a seamless and optimized experience. Today, I'd like to delve into the intriguing partnership between Firefox and Intel Evo technology, specifically focusing on how this collaboration ensures smooth integration, compatibility, and enhances both performance and security features.

Here are some key points to consider as we explore this topic:

Performance Optimization: How does Firefox leverage Intel Evo technology to optimize browsing performance on laptops? Are there specific features or optimizations that take advantage of Intel Evo's hardware capabilities to deliver faster page load times, smoother scrolling, and improved responsiveness?


Battery Efficiency: Intel Evo laptops are known for their energy efficiency and extended battery life. How does Firefox collaborate with Intel Evo technology to ensure that browsing sessions are energy-efficient, minimizing battery drain and maximizing uptime?

Security Features: Security is a top priority for both Firefox and Intel Evo laptops. How do they work together to ensure that users are protected against threats such as malware, phishing, and data breaches? Are there any specific security features or enhancements that result from this collaboration?

Compatibility Assurance: With the diverse range of hardware configurations available in Intel Evo laptops, ensuring compatibility with Firefox is crucial. How does Firefox collaborate with Intel to perform rigorous testing and validation to guarantee that the browser runs smoothly on Intel Evo devices?

I encourage fellow members of the community to share their insights, experiences, and opinions on how Firefox and Intel Evo technology come together to deliver a superior browsing experience. Let's delve into this collaboration and uncover the synergies that benefit users in terms of both performance and security.

Looking forward to an engaging discussion!

I know the proxy address is correct because if I use brave browser instead of firefox (same shell script that launches brave) I can reach the web pages behind the proxy as expected.

title: Glitch in the display of Firefox windows, maybe related to Mac OSX "spaces" and "desktops" fuctionality
content:
Using Mac OSX El Capitan 10.11.6 and Firefox 75.15.0 esr

I have a number of desktops defined in "spaces" and each app goes into one. Something odd has happened with Firefox.

When I select a different Window from the Window dropdown, or from the Dock, sometimes there is a "sliding sideways" effect.

And if I go into Firefox by going to the Dock and tapping its icon - it goes to one window; BUT if go to the Dock and tap again, it changes to another window. I think, always the same two.

So its sort of behaving like "spaces" does, but when I view all the "desktops" in the selection view at the top of the screen, I only see one containing Firefox windows.

Its really annoying when the window changes like that, and I don't know how to get them into a single grouping. I have quit & reopened many times, but it persists.

If I knew which of the Firefox Windows were in each of these glitchy "pseudo-groups" then I might quit all of one group, and then re-open them. Not sure if there are just two such pseudo-groups, or more.
